title: feat: Bump dependencies version
body:
Bump version to the updated riemann-client. (https://github.com/borntyping/rust-riemann_client/pull/6 and https://github.com/borntyping/rust-riemann_client/pull/7)

- Bump riemann client to 0.9.0
- Bump protobuff to 2.20.0

title: feat: add json reporter
body:
Add JSON reporter.

You can use the following options:
- -t to customize the timeout
- -s to customize the interval
- -f to change the destination file where to write the report

If no file is provided, then the JSON is displayed in the console.
If the directory where to create the file does not exist it will fail.

TODO:
- interval should be in milliseconds or should at least allows sending float number.
- documentation

title: fix: allowing scaph to run even if intel_rapl modules r not found
body: this is about https://github.com/hubblo-org/scaphandre/issues/55

title: Ci/#43 add cargo test all in ci
Basic example stack
body:
This is a simple docker-compose stack that run in a single step scaphandre along preconfigured instances of prometheus and grafana. resolve hubblo-org/scaphandre#53

Things that should be done before merging:
* [ ] improve the dashboard (is there somewhere an example of a full featured dashboard, to get started ?)
* [ ] filter out processes : as this stack will typically be used in a end-user workstation / laptop, monitoring and plotting all processes would be overwhelming
* [ ] update corresponding documentation

title: Feat/riemann exporter
body:
First "version" of Riemann exporter.

The implementation was done as a proof of concept. So I tried to do it minimizing the modifications to the existing files.
This is inspired and not so far from the Prometheus one.
As a result it works fine, but there are a lot of duplications in the code currently.

Future improvements could be to:
* Split the run method which is as long as hell.
* Factorize code which is pretty similar in Prometheus and Riemann (mostly run method) in the Exporter trait and just change the way metrics are exposed or sent.

Sorry this PR is a bit large, but it mostly introduced new files, so it can probably be merged without being too worried about it.
Note, I have also fixed a couple of typos in Prometheus exporter.

title: docs: fixing broken link in docs (and adding a few tips in about-containers)
body: fixing https://github.com/hubblo-org/scaphandre/issues/47

title: Docs: Add explanation for how per process power works
body:
Hi Benoit, 

Based on our discussions in #38 , I've written this up to add to the docs in mdbook.

I've left out the info about virtual machine scenarios, and multiple processor scenarios, as I agree with you that they can be address in separate pages, not least to give people who might be up for contributing to a firecracker version some clearer pointers.

### Unable to compile the docs locally though

I'm having a hard time compiling the mdbook docs locally tho, to see these in situ, with a rather cryptic error.

I can't trace the cause of the error as the tracebook doesn't show me where mdbook chokes, but I see the same issue when I try to run a build without any of the new diagrams and text I've added.

Can you let me know if this builds at your end, or if there are any changes you need?

```
~/C/t/scaphandre ❯❯❯ mdbook serve
2021-01-12 13:22:29 [ERROR] (mdbook::utils): Error: Summary parsing failed
2021-01-12 13:22:29 [ERROR] (mdbook::utils): 	Caused By: There was an error parsing the suffix chapters
2021-01-12 13:22:29 [ERROR] (mdbook::utils): 	Caused By: Error at line 21, column 1: Suffix chapters cannot be followed by a list
~/C/t/scaphandre ❯❯❯ mdbook clean
2021-01-12 13:22:43 [ERROR] (mdbook::utils): Error: Summary parsing failed
2021-01-12 13:22:43 [ERROR] (mdbook::utils): 	Caused By: There was an error parsing the suffix chapters
2021-01-12 13:22:43 [ERROR] (mdbook::utils): 	Caused By: Error at line 21, column 1: Suffix chapters cannot be followed by a list
```

For anyone else following along, I've been working in figma at the link below for making these diagrams:

https://www.figma.com/file/MnmCxOZlUWgUiFD0JDN692/understanding-scaphandre?node-id=0%3A1

title: fix: Latest failed tests
body:
@bpetit, I wish you a happy new year ! :tada: 

* All tests and doctests should now run fine using `cargo test`.
* No more warning as well.
* Remove few "dead code".
* Create integration_tests directory if it does not exist.

_Note: as I changed a little the doctests, documentation needs to be regenerated and pushed if needed._

So `cargo test` is fully clean. Even if it is a little thing, I like this because it gives some kind of confidence on the project to new comers
```
running 15 tests
test sensors::tests::get_proc_cpuinfo ... ok
test sensors::tests::read_socket_stats ... ok
test sensors::tests::read_topology_stats ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::joule_equals_1000000microjoules ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::joule_to_milijoules ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::kw_equals_0001megawatt ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::kw_equals_1000w ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::kw_to_milliwatt ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::milijoule_to_joules ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::megawatt_to_microwatt ... ok
test sensors::units::tests::milliwatt_to_watt ... ok
test sensors::utils::tests::process_records_cleaned ... ok
test sensors::utils::tests::process_records_added ... ok
test sensors::tests::read_core_stats ... ok
test sensors::powercap_rapl::tests::get_topology_returns_topology_type ... ok

test result: ok. 15 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

     Running target/debug/deps/scaphandre-837a89c522665b5f

running 0 tests

test result: ok. 0 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

     Running target/debug/deps/integration-2fc570143307fa3f

running 1 test
test exporter_qemu ... ok

test result: ok. 1 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

   Doc-tests scaphandre

running 3 tests
test src/sensors/utils.rs - sensors::utils::ProcessTracker::new (line 18) ... ok
test src/sensors/mod.rs - sensors::Topology::generate_cpu_cores (line 139) ... ok
test src/sensors/utils.rs - sensors::utils::ProcessTracker::add_process_record (line 35) ... ok

test result: ok. 3 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

```

title: Fix/some tests
body:
Sorry @bpetit,

I did not see your comment in the previous PR so quoting it here.

> Thanks for that. This is actually not used in the current implementation of the exporters (I used it in early versions of stdout exporter iirc). But this should b useful for more advanced exporter behaviors. Do you have use cases for that currently ?

In fact, I have no use cases for that currently. I have just run a `cargo test` and several tests failed. As I could manage to fix some of them I simply did it. I think that it is better to have tests on a project that don't fail.

By the way this PR is fixing another one and add a test to the limit into units conversion.

title: Fix units conversions
body: Fix units conversion and add couple of tests.

title: Make init.sh more robust
body:
- Follow shellcheck advises. In particular:
  https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck/wiki/SC2044
- Use strict mode.
- Use read only vars.
- Add a short usage.
- Use explicit functions
- Some stuffs are not useful now, but may help later.

title: Add step_duration option to stdout exporter (issue #27)
body:
@bpetit, please let me know if you want a different description or switches.
Error handling is maybe a bit brutal by making a panic if the value passed is not a numeric one.

title: fix: Fix typos and copy nits in README.md
body:
Hello!

Again, congrats for publishing 0.1.0. 💯  I went over the README and the "_why_" very quickly and overall this is very exciting!

This might be absolute nitpicking for a start, but as I was reading through the README I saw a few contributions I could make wrt typos or copy, so I figured I'd issue a first pull request with those. :-)

---

Unrelated note: I suppose building is only feasible on Linux right now? I'm running on a macOS machine, and tried building but it failed while compiling [`procfs`](https://docs.rs/procfs/0.9.1/procfs/). I'm an absolute Rust newbie, but I assume that's to be expected, given the description of that crate?

> This crate provides to an interface into the linux procfs filesystem, usually mounted at /proc.
